tabs.header_iregular:
We will figure out how to get relief from this sinus pressure.

Relief goals would be to thin and remove the dry and thick mucus that may have formed crusts or caked in the path of sinus drainage.

It would be nice to also shrink the swollen sinus cavity, thereby reducing the pressure in the sinuses.

We would also reduce any inflammation going on. 

With these objectives in mind, see what I recommend below.

collapsable.title: Thin the mucus click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Drink plenty of water

This will help thin dried up mucus and get it moving again making sinus drainage better.

Humidifier

Invest in one. If you don't have one handy, take a steam bath or breathe in steam.

This should help moisturize the nasal passages thinning the mucus.

Saline nasal spray

This will help moisturize the nasal passages improving sinus air flow.

Steam therapy    

A good idea to moisturize the sinuses.

collapsable.title: Decongestant click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Decongestant nasal sprays

 

Pseudoephedrine

collapsable.title: Inflammation click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Anti-inflammatory pain relievers    ​

Ibuprofen, naproxen

2. Steroidal nasal sprays

Triamcinolone acetonide nasal spray.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/02/2016 at 08:35:pm

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what is available over the counter to help with snoring.

Besides the medical devices being advertised on the TV regarding snoring, over the counter pills or liquids do not work.

Breathe right strips may help for a week or two if the cause of the snoring is restricted airflow through the nose such as when you have a cold. Other than that, it is of limited use.

So, we will have to approach this through life style changes. With this in mind, see what is recommended below:

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use over the counter to quiet this cough.

These recommendations assume a minor cough or a cough due to cold, allergy or flu.

Coughing is a reflex action and should be taken seriously if you don't know the cause.

With this in mind, let's go through what is available over-the-counter for cough and use this information to choose a good cough medicine that will give you relief.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Choose the nature of this cough from the list below and see what to use over-the-counter.
fieldset: Productive cough (Coughing up wet mucus)
Feeling of heaviness on the chest
I get headaches when I cough, goes away when I stop coughing
Haven't slept for more than 3 nights since this cough.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

We must have left some things out. Please choose what best describes what you are experiencing and let's see how to help.
mode.2: Something to prevent?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have this cough really bad.

Need to see a doctor or healthcare professional.
mode.4:
Seek Urgent Care
Using over-the-counter medication is not recommended.

You will need to see a healthcare professional for this. 

Don't use any over-the-counter medicine. Not only is it going to prolong the problem and make it worse, you will also be wasting your money.
mode.5: Selection require dextromethorphan.
mode.6: Selection require guaifenesin.
mode.7: Selection require cough drops
mode.8: Selection require decongestant.
mode.9: Selection require an antihistamine.
mode.10: Symptoms require dextromethorphan and guaifenesin
mode.11: Symptoms require dextromethorphan and cough drops
mode.12: Symptoms require dextromethorphan and a decongestant
mode.13: Symptoms require dextromethorphan and an antihistamine.
mode.14: Symptoms require guaifenesin and cough drops
mode.15: Symptoms require guaifenesin and a decongestant
mode.16: Symptoms require guaifenesin and an antihistamine
mode.17: Symptoms require cough drops and a decongestant
mode.18: Symptoms require cough drops and an antihistamine
mode.19: Symptoms require a decongestant and an antihistamine
mode.20: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, guaifenesin and cough drops.
mode.21: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, guaifenesin and a decongestant
mode.22: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, guaifenesin and an antihistamine
mode.23: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, cough drops and a decongestant
mode.24: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, cough drops and an antihistamine
mode.25: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, decongestant and an antihistamine
mode.26: Symptoms require guaifenesin, cough drops and a decongestant
mode.27: Symptoms require guaifenesin, cough drops and an antihistamine
mode.28: Symptoms require guaifenesin, decongestant and an antihistamine
mode.29: Symptoms require cough drops, decongestant and an antihistamine
mode.30: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, guaifenesin, cough drops and a decongestant
mode.31: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, guaifenesin, cough drops and an antihistamine
mode.32: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, guaifenesin, decongestant and an antihistamine
mode.33: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, cough drops, decongestant and an antihistamine
mode.34: Symptoms require guaifenesin, cough drops, decongestant and an antihistamine
mode.35: Symptoms require dextromethorphan, guaifenesin, cough drops, decongestant and an antihistamine
mode.50: Oops!, You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 02/03/2016

collapsable.title: Dextromethorphan (DM) click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
DM is a cough suppressant that decreases activities in the part of the brain that controls the coughing reflex.

It is best for a dry and irritating cough where no mucus or phlegm is being produced. With a wet cough, you don't want to suppress it. You will need to cough it out. The only time you will need a cough suppressant if a cough is wet is to control coughing at night or if this cough is very bad and giving you chest pain.

Delsym or store brands

collapsable.title: Guaifenesin click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This is an expectorant. It helps loosen thick, dried up mucus in the throat and chest so it is easier for you to cough up.

You will take this if you are experiencing chest congestion and coughing up stuff. If it is a dry cough, skip this.

You need to drink a lot of water for this to work. Keep drinking water throughout the day not just when taking the medication. Because you need to keep the throat moist or lubricated so the mucus can flow.

collapsable.title: Cough Drops click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This is better for a dry, irritating, scratchy, and tickling cough. Look for one with honey added to it. Honey should help with suppressing the cough.

Know that some brands contain dextromethorphan. Do not use this with dextromethorphan syrup or DM tablets. It is one or the other.

collapsable.title: Decongestant click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
The recommended decongestant is Pseudoephedrine. You will need to get this at the pharmacy counter using your driver's license. This should reduce the nasal congestion, sinus pressure, and increase the drainage of sinus secretions.

Stay away from phenylephrine. If the pharmacy is closed, go with a decongestant nasal spray instead.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
If fluid draining to the back of the throat is causing this cough, you will need to include an antihistamine.

You will also need this if you are experiencing a night time cough or the cough is keeping you awake at night.

Go with the antihistamine called diphenhydramine. This will dry up the drainage, get you some sleep and also work on the cough. 

If you need something during the day, chlorpheniramine will be your best bet. This causes less drowsiness which is manageable to most people during the day.

collapsable.title: Dextromethorphan click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
DM is a cough suppressant that decreases activities in the part of the brain that controls the coughing reflex.

It is best for a dry and irritating cough where no mucus or phlegm is being produced. With a wet cough, you don't want to suppress it. You will need to cough it out. The only time you will need a cough suppressant if a cough is wet is to control coughing at night or if this cough is very bad and giving you chest pain.

Delsym or store brands

collapsable.title: Guaifenesin click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This is an expectorant. It helps loosen thick, dried up mucus in the throat and chest so it is easier for you to cough up.

You will take this if you are experiencing chest congestion and coughing up stuff. If it is a dry cough, skip this.

You need to drink a lot of water for this to work.

Keep drinking water throughout the day not just when taking the medication. Because you need to keep the throat moist or lubricated so the mucus can flow.

collapsable.title: Cough Drops click to expand contents
Decongestant click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
The recommended decongestant is Pseudoephedrine. You will need to get this at the pharmacy counter using your driver's license. This should reduce the nasal congestion, sinus pressure, and increase the drainage of sinus secretions.

Stay away from phenylephrine. If the pharmacy is closed, go with a decongestant nasal spray instead.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
If fluid draining to the back of the throat is causing this cough, you will need to include an antihistamine.

You will also need this if you are experiencing a night time cough or the cough is keeping you awake at night.

Go with the antihistamine calleddiphenhydramine. This will dry up the drainage, get you some sleep and also work on the cough. 

If you need something during the day, chlorpheniramine will be your best bet. This causes less drowsiness which is manageable to most people during the day.

collapsable.title: Combination Products click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Guaifenesin + Dextromethorphan

Take this if you have a wet or a productive cough and this cough is keeping you up at night or you just can't stop coughing.

Stay away if it is just a wet cough. You need to keep things moving or prevent the mucus from getting too far into the respiratory tracts. You need a cough reflex for this protective mechanism.

Examples: Mucinex DM, Robitussin DM, Store brands    ​

Guaifenesin + Pseudoephedrine

This combines an expectorant with a decongestant. You will get this at the pharmacy counter because of the pseudoephedrine.
Mucinex D    ​

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Drink Plenty of Water    ​

2. Honey    ​

3. Steam showers

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's find something for this sore throat over the counter.

This assumes this sore throat is a result of minor irritation or inflammation. The most common cause (80% of the time) being of viral origin.

If you think you are looking at a bacterial cause, seek urgent care. Nothing over-the-counter will work on that.

With this in mind, let's see what is recommended over-the-counter for a sore throat.

collapsable.title: NSAIDS click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Non-Steroidal Antiinflammatory Drugs (NSAIDS) will help with the pain and inflammation of this soreness of the throat.

If the throat also feels swollen, this would be your first choice to reduce the pain and swelling.

Ibuprofen, Naproxen are good examples.

collapsable.title: Acetaminophen click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will take acetaminophen if the throat is not swollen. This will only help with the pain and not the inflammation of the throat linings.

Take acetaminophen however if a sore throat also includes a headache. Acetaminophen is better for headaches than NSAIDS.

collapsable.title: Sprays / Lozenges click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These help you target the pain where it hurts. They may soothe the affected area but relief is usually short-lived.

Spray or lozenges. Which should you choose?

Well, the lozenges are easier to carry around but their value also lies in moisturizing the throat which is a requirement if you have a sore throat. You want the throat to be constantly moisturized.

But if the pain is towards the back of the throat or deep down the throat, a spray will be better. It is better at targeting the pain.

collapsable.title: Worth Doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Gargle with salt water. Do this often.

2. Sucking on hard candy to keep the throat moist

3. Drink water more frequently. 

4. Use humidifier when sleeping to prevent dry throat on waking up in the morning. Do this especially if you also have nasal congestion. Because at some point you may be breathing through your mouth. This will dry up the throat quickly and make a sore throat very bad.

5. Tea + Lemon

6. Hot soup

7. Gargle with ice chips.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/03/2016
